Calculating Other Probabilities

In this Section, we see how to calculate probabilities represented by areas other than those of the type shown in the previous Section.

Case 1

The below Figure illustrates what we do if both \(Z\) values are positive. By using the properties of the standard normal distribution we can organise matters so that any required area is always of ‘standard form’.


Example

Find the probability that \(Z\) takes values between \(1\) and \(2\).

Solution

Using the Standard Normal Table:

\(\text{P}(0 < Z < z_2)\) i.e. \(\text{P}(0 < Z < 2) = 0.4772\)

\(\text{P}(0 < Z < z_1)\) i.e. \(\text{P}(0 < Z < 1) = 0.3413\)

Hence \(\text{P}(1 < Z < 2) = 0.4772 − 0.3413 = 0.1359\)

Remember that with a continuous distribution, \(\text{P}(Z = 1)\) is meaningless (will have zero probability) so that \(\text{P}(1 ≤ Z ≤ 2)\) is interpreted as \(\text{P}(1 < Z < 2)\).

Case 2

The following diagram illustrates the procedure to be followed when finding probabilities of the form \(\text{P}(Z>z_1)\).


Example

What is the probability that \(Z>2\)?

Solution

\(\text{P}(0 < Z < 2) = 0.4772\) (from the Table). Hence the probability is \(0.5 − 0.4772\) \(= 0.0228\).

Case 3

Here we consider the procedure to be followed when calculating probabilities of the form \(\text{P}(Z<z_1)\). Here the shaded area is the sum of the left-hand half of the total area and a ‘standard’ area.


Example

What is the probability that \(Z<2\)?

Solution

\(\text{P}(Z < 2) = 0.5 + 0.4772 = 0.9772.\)

Case 4

Here we consider what needs to be done when calculating probabilities of the form
\(\text{P}(-z_1<Z<0)\) where \(z_1\) is positive. This time we make use of the symmetry in the standard normal distribution curve.


Example

What is the probability that \(-2<Z<0\)?

Solution

The area is equal to that corresponding to \(\text{P}(0 < Z < 2) = 0.4772.\)

Case 5

Finally we consider probabilities of the form \(\text{P}(-z_1<Z<z_2)\). Here we use the sum property and the symmetry property.


Example

What is the probability that \(-1<Z<2\)?

Solution

\(\text{P}(−1 < Z < 0) = \text{P}(0 < Z < 1) = 0.3413\)

\(\text{P}(0 < Z < 2) = 0.4772\)

Hence the required probability \(\text{P}(−1 < Z < 2)\) is \(0.8185.\)

Other cases can be handed by a combination of the ideas already used.
